title: Contributing to presize
text: contribute modifications additions code, create PR. steps broadly follows. Fork presize GitHub profile. Clone local machine. Make changes commit local git. Push changes GitHub. Create PR Discuss reviewer requested changes PR can closed. Please describe motivation behind PR provide unit tests via testthat. PR addresses issue, add info description e.g. closes #{issue-number}

title: `presize`
text: preparation trial estimate sensitivity specificity mobile colposcope, device detecting tissue abnormality, sample size calculation made estimate precision sensitivity device. best guess sensitivity 75% prevalence 15% desired sample size 250 participants. , question answered wide confidence interval going scenario? plug values prec_sens (precision sensitivity) function follows see 250 participants, confidence interval 59% (lwr) 86% (upr). Note Wilson’s method calculating confidence intervals adjusts point estimate allow calculation symmetrical CI. sensadj variable. measures multiple methods available. case prec_sens (well prec_spec prec_prop), four different approaches creating confidence intervals, yielding slightly different results. specificity, use prec_spec function instead. demonstration purposes, can also change method used calculate CI. Using functions presize . instance precision mean 60 SD 10 40 observations calculated follows.
code: (ss <- prec_sens(sens   = .75,  # sensitivity                   prev   = .15,  # prevalence                  ntot   = 250,  # sample size                  method = "wilson")) #> estimating n from 'ntot' and 'prev' #>  #>      precision for a sensitivity with Wilson confidence interval.  #>  #>   sens   sensadj  n prev ntot conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1 0.75 0.7270475 38 0.15  250  0.2663919       0.95 0.5938516 0.8602435 #>  #> NOTE: sensadj is the adjusted sensitivity, from which the ci is calculated. #>       n is the number of positives, ntot the full sample prec_spec(spec   = .75,  # specificity            prev   = .15,  # prevalence           ntot   = 250,  # sample size           method = "exact") #> estimating n from 'ntot' and 'prev' #>  #>      precision for a specificity with exact confidence interval.  #>  #>   spec specadj   n prev ntot conf.width conf.level       lwr      upr #> 1 0.75      NA 213 0.15  250  0.1203922       0.95 0.6862538 0.806646 #>  #> NOTE: specadj is the adjusted specificity, from which the ci is calculated. #>       n is the number of negatives, ntot the full sample. prec_mean(60, sd = 10, n = 40) #>  #>      precision for mean  #>  #>   mean sd  n conf.width conf.level      lwr      upr #> 1   60 10 40    6.39631       0.95 56.80184 63.19816

title: `presize`
text: fixing sample size sometimes necessary, common select sample size based given precision. might want achieve sensitivity given amount (e.g. plus-minus 5%). also possible presize. Using code , replace ntot argument conf.width argument. scenario, 1904 participants (approximately 286 condition) yield CI width 0.1 (10%), average. functions presize similar options, although sample size argument generally n instead ntot (prec_sens prec_spec special can pass either number individuals condition detected n, pass ntot prev get CI width mixed group case n derived ntot prev). calculations sensitivity can also preformed number cases rather total number prevalence available. instance, 50 individuals condition expect sensitivity 60%, can put values instead. Sensitivities specificities just proportions prec_prop can also used latter example. Using functions presize . instance, sample size obtain CI width 5 units mean 60 SD 10 calculated follows.
code: (ss <- prec_sens(sens       = .75,   # sensitivity                   prev       = .15,   # prevalence                  conf.width = .1,    # CI width                  method     = "wilson")) #>  #>      sample size for a sensitivity with Wilson confidence interval.  #>  #>   sens   sensadj        n prev     ntot conf.width conf.level       lwr #> 1 0.75 0.7466814 285.5428 0.15 1903.619        0.1       0.95 0.6966814 #>         upr #> 1 0.7966814 #>  #> NOTE: sensadj is the adjusted sensitivity, from which the ci is calculated. #>       n is the number of positives, ntot the full sample prec_sens(.6, n = 50, method = "wilson") #>  #>      precision for a sensitivity with Wilson confidence interval.  #>  #>   sens   sensadj  n prev ntot conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1  0.6 0.5928652 50   NA   NA  0.2621017       0.95 0.4618144 0.7239161 #>  #> NOTE: sensadj is the adjusted sensitivity, from which the ci is calculated. #>       n is the number of positives, ntot the full sample prec_prop(.6, n = 50, method = "wilson") #>  #>      precision for a proportion with Wilson confidence interval.  #>  #>     p      padj  n conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1 0.6 0.5928652 50  0.2621017       0.95 0.4618144 0.7239161 #>  #> NOTE: padj is the adjusted proportion, from which the ci is calculated. prec_mean(60, sd = 10, conf.width = 5) #>  #>      sample size for mean  #>  #>   mean sd       n conf.width conf.level  lwr  upr #> 1   60 10 63.8979          5       0.95 57.5 62.5

title: `presize`
text: common vague idea expect terms SDs, sensitivities, etc, often worthwhile creating set scenarios. Returning colposcope example … want see CI width varies different sensitivities. presize, ’s easy run different scenarios, simply passing multiple values parameter (multiple values passed, length!). varying single parameter, scenarios can created seq passed appropriate presize functions argument. vary sensitivity 50% 95% steps 5%. can also use expand.grid pass scenarios varying multiple parameters simultaneously. vary sensitivity, prevalence sample size. print method, see details individual scenarios. default print method presize objects prints first 10 rows, fact 30 rows (also print function, n option define many rows print, e.g. print(scenario_data, n = 5) can used print first five rows). Using .data.frame method, can convert list returned prec_sens dataframe can create tables figures. multiple scenarios calculated, plotting can particularly informative. ggplot2, example, particularly useful . show CI width function sensitivity, parameters chosen instead.  also create table scenarios containing CIs. select scenarios sensitivities 70% reshape format table use gt package print nice table HTML.

0.4420956 0.7395424 #> 4  0.65 0.6362285 38 0.15  250  0.2903543       0.95 0.4910514 0.7814056 #> 5  0.70 0.6816380 38 0.15  250  0.2801231       0.95 0.5415765 0.8216996 #> 6  0.75 0.7270475 38 0.15 sensitivity, from which the ci is calculated. #>       n is the number of positives, ntot the full sample scenarios <- expand.grid(sens = seq(.5, .95, .1),                          prev = seq(.1, .2, .04),                          ntot = c(250, 350))  (scenario_data <- prec_sens(sens = scenarios$sens,                              prev = scenarios$prev,                              ntot = scenarios$ntot,                              method = "wilson")) #> estimating n from 'ntot' and 'prev' #>  #>      precision for a sensitivity with Wilson confidence interval.  #>  #>    sens   sensadj  n prev ntot conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1   0.5 0.5000000 25 0.10  250  0.3649551       0.95 0.3175224 0.6824776 #> 2   0.6 0.5866808 25 0.10  250  0.3585724       0.95 0.4073946 0.7659670 #> 3   0.7 0.6733615 25 0.10  250  0.3387033       0.95 0.5040099 0.8427132 #> 4   0.8 0.7600423 25 0.10  250  0.3027037       0.95 0.6086905 0.9113942 #> 5   0.9 0.8467231 25 0.10  250  0.2435219       0.95 0.7249621 0.9684841 #> 6   0.5 0.5000000 35 0.14  250  0.3144853       0.95 0.3427574 0.6572426 #> 7   0.6 0.5901099 35 0.14  250  0.3087656       0.95 0.4357271 0.7444927 #> 8   0.7 0.6802198 35 0.14  250  0.2909327       0.95 0.5347534 0.8256862 #> 9   0.8 0.7703297 35 0.14  250  0.2584917       0.95 0.6410839 0.8995755 #> 10  0.9 0.8604396 35 0.14  250  0.2046081       0.95 0.7581356 0.9627436 #>  #>  [Output truncated at 10 of 30 rows] #> NOTE: sensadj is the adjusted sensitivity, from which the ci is calculated. #>       n is the number of positives, ntot the full sample scenario_df <- as.data.frame(scenario_data)  library(ggplot2)  ggplot(scenario_df,         aes(x = sens,             y = conf.width,             # convert colour to factor for distinct colours rather than a continuum            col = as.factor(prev),             group = prev)) +   geom_line() +   labs(x = "Sensitivity", y = "CI width", col = "Prevalence") +    facet_wrap(vars(ntot)) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(tidyr) library(magrittr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'magrittr' #> The following object is masked from 'package:tidyr': #>  #>     extract library(gt)  scenario_df %>%    # create the values needed specifically for the table   mutate(     txt = sprintf("%3.1f - %3.1f", lwr * 100, upr * 100),     `Prevalence (%)` = prev * 100,     Sensitivity = sens * 100,     ntot = sprintf("N = %1.0f", ntot)) %>%    # select particular scenarios and variables to keep   filter(sens > .7) %>%    select(ntot, Sensitivity, `Prevalence (%)`, txt) %>%    # reshape   pivot_wider(     names_from = Sensitivity,      values_from = txt,      id_cols = c(`Prevalence (%)`, ntot)) %>%    # group by ntot to split the table a little   group_by(ntot) %>%   # create the table   gt() %>%    # add a header   tab_spanner(     label = "Sensitivity (%)",     columns = 2:4   ) %>%    cols_align("center", columns = 2:4) %>%    # increase the spacing between cells   tab_style(     style = "padding-left:12;padding-right:12;",     locations = cells_body()   )

title: Precision Based Sample Size Calculation
text: Bland (2009) recommended base study sizes width confidence interval rather power statistical test. goal presize provide functions precision based sample size calculations. given sample size, functions return precision (width confidence interval), vice versa.

title: Precision Based Sample Size Calculation
text: presize provides functions 1 Simple wrappers prec_prop. 2 Wrappers prec_lr values provided via sens spec

title: Precision Based Sample Size Calculation
text: Suppose want estimate proportion hospital admissions diabetes. Diabetes prevalence approximately 10% (Emerging Risk Factors Collaboration et al. (2010)). assume slightly higher proportion diabetics, 15%, diabetes risk factor wide range conditions. want estimate prevalence diabetes within 5% (plus/minus 2.5%). presize, simple. use prec_prop (precision proportion) function pass 15% 5% arguments p conf.width: n column, see need ask 784 (rounding 783.5 ) patients achieve desired CI width. Disappointingly, also know funds collect data 600 patients. wonder 600 patients yield sufficient precision - also accept CI width 6% (plus/minus 3%). case, can pass arguments p n. Now see 600 patients, CI width 5.7%. happy continue planning study values. functions listed Table 1 can used similarly. can also look range scenarios simulatenously passing vector one arguments, used create something analogous power curve:
code: library(presize) # load the package prec_prop(p = 0.15, conf.width = 0.05) #> Warning in prec_prop(p = 0.15, conf.width = 0.05): more than one method was #> chosen, 'wilson' will be used #>  #>      sample size for a proportion with Wilson confidence interval.  #>  #>      p      padj        n conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1 0.15 0.1517077 783.4897       0.05       0.95 0.1267077 0.1767077 #>  #> NOTE: padj is the adjusted proportion, from which the ci is calculated. prec_prop(p = 0.15, n = 600) #> Warning in prec_prop(p = 0.15, n = 600): more than one method was chosen, #> 'wilson' will be used #>  #>      precision for a proportion with Wilson confidence interval.  #>  #>      p      padj   n conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1 0.15 0.1522266 600 0.05713404       0.95 0.1236596 0.1807936 #>  #> NOTE: padj is the adjusted proportion, from which the ci is calculated. prec_prop(p = 0.15, n = seq(600, 800, 50)) #> Warning in prec_prop(p = 0.15, n = seq(600, 800, 50)): more than one method was #> chosen, 'wilson' will be used #>  #>      precision for a proportion with Wilson confidence interval.  #>  #>      p      padj   n conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1 0.15 0.1522266 600 0.05713404       0.95 0.1236596 0.1807936 #> 2 0.15 0.1520563 650 0.05489329       0.95 0.1246097 0.1795030 #> 3 0.15 0.1519102 700 0.05289705       0.95 0.1254617 0.1783588 #> 4 0.15 0.1517835 750 0.05110386       0.95 0.1262316 0.1773355 #> 5 0.15 0.1516726 800 0.04948148       0.95 0.1269319 0.1764133 #>  #> NOTE: padj is the adjusted proportion, from which the ci is calculated.

text: auc AUC value. prev prevalence. n number observations. conf.width precision (full width confidence interval). conf.level confidence level. ... arguments optimize.

title: Sample size or precision for AUC — prec_auc
text: Object class "presize", list arguments (including   computed one) augmented method note elements.

title: Sample size or precision for AUC — prec_auc

title: Sample size or precision for AUC — prec_auc
code: # confidence interval width N <- 500 prev <- .1 auc <- .65 (prec <- prec_auc(auc, prev, n = N)) #>  #>      precision for AUC  #>  #>    auc   n prev n1  n2       lwr       upr conf.width conf.level #> 1 0.65 500  0.1 50 450 0.5639623 0.7360377  0.1720755       0.95 cwidth <- prec$conf.width # sample size prec_auc(auc, prev, conf.width = cwidth) #>  #>      sample size for AUC  #>  #>    auc   n prev n1  n2       lwr       upr conf.width conf.level #> 1 0.65 500  0.1 50 450 0.5639623 0.7360377  0.1720755       0.95

title: Sample size or precision for correlation coefficient — prec_cor
text: r desired correlation coefficient. n sample size. conf.width precision (full width confidence interval). conf.level confidence level. method Exactly one pearson (default), kendall, spearman. Methods can abbreviated. ... options uniroot (e.g. tol)

title: Sample size or precision for correlation coefficient — prec_cor
text: Object class "presize", list arguments (including   computed one) augmented method note elements.

title: Sample size or precision for correlation coefficient — prec_cor
text: Exactly one parameters n conf.width must passed NULL, parameter determined . Sample size precision calculated according formula 2 Bonett Wright (2000). use pearson recommended, \(n \ge 25\). pearson correlation coefficient assumes bivariate normality. assumption bivariate normality met, spearman kendall considered. n rounded next whole number using ceiling. uniroot used solve n.

title: Sample size or precision for correlation coefficient — prec_cor

code: # calculate confidence interval width... # Pearson correlation coefficient prec_cor(r = 0.5, n = 100) #> Warning: more than one method was chosen, 'pearson' will be used #>  #>      precision for pearson 's correlation coefficient  #>  #>     r   n conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1 0.5 100  0.2974965       0.95 0.3366433 0.6341398 # Kendall rank correlation coefficient (tau) prec_cor(r = 0.5, n = 100, method = "kendall") #>  #>      precision for kendall 's correlation coefficient  #>  #>     r   n conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1 0.5 100  0.1980633       0.95 0.3944584 0.5925217 # Spearman's rank correlation coefficient prec_cor(r = 0.5, n = 100, method = "spearman") #>  #>      precision for spearman 's correlation coefficient  #>  #>     r   n conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1 0.5 100  0.3154053       0.95 0.3258966 0.6413019 # calculate N required for a given confidence interval width... # Pearson correlation coefficient prec_cor(r = 0.5, conf.width = .15) #> Warning: more than one method was chosen, 'pearson' will be used #>  #>      sample size for pearson 's correlation coefficient  #>  #>     r   n conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1 0.5 387       0.15       0.95 0.4213129 0.5712155 # Kendall rank correlation coefficient (tau) prec_cor(r = 0.5, conf.width = .15, method = "kendall") #>  #>      sample size for kendall 's correlation coefficient  #>  #>     r   n conf.width conf.level       lwr      upr #> 1 0.5 172       0.15       0.95 0.4213599 0.571177 # Spearman's rank correlation coefficient prec_cor(r = 0.5, conf.width = .15, method = "spearman") #>  #>      sample size for spearman 's correlation coefficient  #>  #>     r   n conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1 0.5 435       0.15       0.95 0.4213129 0.5712155

This can be done via prec_icc(0.85, 4, conf.width = 0.2) #>  #>      sample size for intraclass correlation  #>  #>    rho k  n conf.width conf.level #> 1 0.85 4 20        0.2       0.95 #>  # note that \code{presamp} rounds up to the nearist integer.  # Bonett then goes on to estimate the width given the sample size, finding a # value 'close to 0.2': prec_icc(0.85, 4, 20) #>  #>      precision for intraclass correlation  #>  #>    rho k  n conf.width conf.level #> 1 0.85 4 20  0.1954993       0.95 #>

code: # precision based on sample size #   two categories with proportions of 30 and 70\%, four raters prec_kappa(kappa = .5, n = 200, raters = 4, n_category = 2, props = c(.3,.7)) #>  #>      precision for Cohen's kappa  #>  #>   kappa   n   lwr   upr conf.width conf.level #> 1   0.5 200 0.425 0.575       0.15       0.95 # sample size to get a given precision prec_kappa(kappa = .5, conf.width = .15, raters = 4, n_category = 2,            props = c(.3,.7)) #>  #>      sample size for Cohen's kappa  #>  #>   kappa   n   lwr   upr conf.width conf.level #> 1   0.5 198 0.425 0.575       0.15       0.95  # as above, but with two scenarios for kappa prec_kappa(kappa = c(.5, .75), conf.width = .15, raters = 4, n_category = 2,            props = c(.3,.7)) #>  #>      sample size for Cohen's kappa  #>  #>   kappa   n   lwr   upr conf.width conf.level #> 1  0.50 198 0.425 0.575       0.15       0.95 #> 2  0.75 155 0.675 0.825       0.15       0.95 prec_kappa(kappa = c(.5, .75), conf.width = c(.15, 0.3), raters = 4,            n_category = 2, props = c(.3,.7)) #>  #>      sample size for Cohen's kappa  #>  #>   kappa   n   lwr   upr conf.width conf.level #> 1  0.50 198 0.425 0.575       0.15       0.95 #> 2  0.75  44 0.600 0.900       0.30       0.95

title: Sample size or precision for likelihood ratios — prec_lr
text: Object class "presize", list arguments (including   computed one) augmented method note elements.

title: Sample size or precision for likelihood ratios — prec_lr
text: functions implement formula 10 Simel et al 1991. prec_lr generalized function allowing many scenarios, prec_pos_lr prec_neg_lr specific positive negative likelihood ratios 2*2 setting (e.g. disease status test positive/negative). positive likelihood ratio (LR+), 2x2 style experiment, p1 sensitivity, p2 1-specificity. Alternatively, use prec_pos_lr. negative likelihood ratio (LR-), 2x2 style experiment, p1 1-sensitivity, p2 specificity. Alternatively, use prec_neg_lr. conditional likelihood ratios 3x2 tables, positive negative tests inconclusive ones (yields), p1 proportion positive negative tests diseased group p2 proportion positive negative tests non-diseased group.

title: Sample size or precision for likelihood ratios — prec_lr
text: prec_pos_lr(): "Positive likelihood ratio" prec_neg_lr(): "Negative likelihood ratio"

title: Sample size or precision for likelihood ratios — prec_lr
text: Simel, DL, Samsa, GP Matchar, DB (1991) Likelihood ratios confidence: Sample size estimation diagnostic test studies. J Clin Epidemiol 44(8), 763-770

title: Sample size or precision for likelihood ratios — prec_lr
code: # equal numbers of diseased/non-diseased, 80% sens, 73% spec, 74 participants total prec_lr(.5, .8, .27, 74) #>  #>      precision for likelihood ratios  #>  #>   prev  p1   p2  n n1 n2       lr      lwr     upr conf.width conf.level #> 1  0.5 0.8 0.27 74 37 37 2.962963 1.703046 5.15497   3.451925       0.95  # Simel et al 1991, problem 1 - LR+ CI width from N # Sensitivity of a new test is at least 80%, specificity is 73% and the LR+ # is 2.96 (= 0.8/(1-0.73)). We have as many diseased as not diseased # (n1 = n2, n = 2*n1 = 146.8, prevalence = .5) prec_lr(prev = .5, p1 = .8, p2 = 1-.73, n = 146.8) #>  #>      precision for likelihood ratios  #>  #>   prev  p1   p2     n   n1   n2       lr      lwr      upr conf.width #> 1  0.5 0.8 0.27 146.8 73.4 73.4 2.962963 1.999739 4.390147   2.390407 #>   conf.level #> 1       0.95 prec_pos_lr(prev = .5, sens = .8, spec = .73, n = 146.8) #>  #>      precision for positive likelihood ratio  #>  #>   prev  p1   p2     n   n1   n2       lr      lwr      upr conf.width #> 1  0.5 0.8 0.27 146.8 73.4 73.4 2.962963 1.999739 4.390147   2.390407 #>   conf.level #> 1       0.95  # problem 1 of Simel et al actually derives n1 rather than the width of the # confidence interval (ie N from CI width). If we know that the lower limit # of the CI should be 2.0, the confidence interval width is approximately # exp(2*(log(2.96) - log(2))) = 2.19 (approximate because the CI Of the LR # is only symetrical on the log(LR) scale), which we can put in conf.width prec_lr(prev = .5, p1 = .8, p2 = 1-.73, conf.width = 2.2) #>  #>      sample size for likelihood ratios  #>  #>   prev  p1   p2        n       n1       n2       lr      lwr      upr #> 1  0.5 0.8 0.27 172.0183 86.00915 86.00915 2.962963 2.060562 4.260562 #>   conf.width conf.level #> 1        2.2       0.95 # same, but using the wrapper to specify sens and spec prec_pos_lr(prev = .5, sens = .8, spec = .73, conf.width = 2.2) #>  #>      sample size for positive likelihood ratio  #>  #>   prev  p1   p2        n       n1       n2       lr      lwr      upr #> 1  0.5 0.8 0.27 172.0183 86.00915 86.00915 2.962963 2.060562 4.260562 #>   conf.width conf.level #> 1        2.2       0.95  # Simel et al 1991, problem 2 - LR- CI width from N # p1 = 1 - sens = .1, p2 = spec = .5 # n1 = n2, n = 160, prev = .5 prec_lr(prev = .5, p1 = .1, p2 = .5, n = 160) #>  #>      precision for likelihood ratios  #>  #>   prev  p1  p2   n n1 n2  lr       lwr       upr conf.width conf.level #> 1  0.5 0.1 0.5 160 80 80 0.2 0.1000195 0.3999219  0.2999024       0.95 # same, but using the wrapper to specify sens and spec prec_neg_lr(prev = .5, sens = .9, spec = .5, n = 160) #>  #>      precision for negative likelihood ratio  #>  #>   prev  p1  p2   n n1 n2  lr       lwr       upr conf.width conf.level #> 1  0.5 0.1 0.5 160 80 80 0.2 0.1000195 0.3999219  0.2999024       0.95

code: # confidence interval width for a rate of 2.5 events per unit and 20 events, #  using the score method prec_rate(2.5, x = 20, met = "score") #>  #>      precision for a rate with score confidence interval  #>  #>     r     radj  x time conf.width conf.level      lwr      upr #> 1 2.5 2.740091 20    8   2.243301       0.95 1.618441 3.861742 #>  #> NOTE: 'x / r' units of time are needed to accumulate 'x' events. #>  # number of events to yield a CI width of 2.243 for a rate of 2.5 events per #  unit and 20 events, using the score method prec_rate(2.5, conf.width = 2.243, met = "score") #>  #>      sample size for a rate with score confidence interval  #>  #>     r    radj        x     time conf.width conf.level     lwr     upr #> 1 2.5 2.74003 20.00514 8.002055      2.243       0.95 1.61853 3.86153 #>  #> NOTE: 'x / r' units of time are needed to accumulate 'x' events. #>  # confidence interval width for a rate of 2.5 events per unit and 20 events, #  using the exact method prec_rate(2.5, x = 20, met = "exact") #>  #>      precision for a rate with exact confidence interval  #>  #>     r radj  x time conf.width conf.level      lwr      upr #> 1 2.5  2.5 20    8   2.333982       0.95 1.527065 3.861047 #>  #> NOTE: 'x / r' units of time are needed to accumulate 'x' events. #>  # vs and wald have the same conf.width, but different lwr and upr prec_rate(2.5, x = 20, met = "vs") #>  #>      precision for a rate with vs confidence interval  #>  #>     r     radj  x time conf.width conf.level      lwr      upr #> 1 2.5 2.620046 20    8   2.191306       0.95 1.524392 3.715699 #>  #> NOTE: 'x / r' units of time are needed to accumulate 'x' events. #>  prec_rate(2.5, x = 20, met = "wald") #>  #>      precision for a rate with wald confidence interval  #>  #>     r radj  x time conf.width conf.level      lwr      upr #> 1 2.5  2.5 20    8   2.191306       0.95 1.404347 3.595653 #>  #> NOTE: 'x / r' units of time are needed to accumulate 'x' events. #>

text: p1 risk among exposed. p2 risk among unexposed. n1 number patients exposed group. conf.width precision (full width confidence interval). r allocation ratio (relative size exposed unexposed cohort (n1 / n2)). conf.level confidence level. method Exactly one newcombe (default), mn (Miettinen-Nurminen), ac (Agresti-Caffo), wald. Methods can abbreviated. ... options uniroot (e.g. tol)

title: Sample size or precision for risk difference — prec_riskdiff
text: Exactly one parameters n1 conf.width must passed NULL, parameter determined . Newcombe (newcombe) proposed confidence interval based wilson score method single proportion (see prec_prop). confidence interval without continuity correction implemented equation 10 Newcombe (1998). Miettinen-Nurminen (mn) provide closed equation restricted maximum likelihood estimate . implementation based code provided Yongyi Min https://users.stat.ufl.edu/~aa/cda/R/two-sample/R2/index.html. Agresti-Caffo (ac) confidence interval based Wald confidence interval, adding 1 success cell 2 x 2 table (see Agresti Caffo 2000). uniroot used solve n newcombe, ac, mn method.

title: Sample size or precision for risk difference — prec_riskdiff
text: Agresti (2003) Categorical Data Analysis, Second Edition, Wiley Series Probability Statistics, doi:10.1002/0471249688 . Agresti Caffo B (2000) Simple Effective Confidence Intervals Proportions Differences Proportions Result Adding Two Successes Two Failures, American Statistician, 54(4):280-288. Miettinen O Nurminen M (1985) Comparative analysis two rates, Statistics Medicine, 4:213-226. Newcombe RG (1998) Interval estimation difference independent proportions: comparison eleven methods, Statistics Medicine, 17:873-890. Fagerland MW, Lydersen S, Laake P (2015). Recommended confidence intervals two independent binomial proportions, Statistical methods medical research 24(2):224-254.

code: # proportions of 40 and 30\%, 50 participants, how wide is the CI? prec_riskdiff(p1 = .4, p2 = .3, n1 = 50) #> Warning: more than one method was chosen, 'newcombe' will be used #>  #>      precision for a risk difference with newcombe confidence interval  #>  #>    p1  p2 n1 n2 ntot r delta         lwr       upr conf.width conf.level #> 1 0.4 0.3 50 50  100 1   0.1 -0.08510109 0.2759788  0.3610798       0.95 # proportions of 40 and 30\%, 50 participants, how many participants for a CI 0.2 wide? prec_riskdiff(p1 = .4, p2 = .3, conf.width = .2) #> Warning: more than one method was chosen, 'newcombe' will be used #>  #>      sample size for a risk difference with newcombe confidence interval  #>  #>    p1  p2       n1       n2     ntot r delta          lwr       upr conf.width #> 1 0.4 0.3 169.8394 169.8394 339.6787 1   0.1 -0.001408915 0.1985911        0.2 #>   conf.level #> 1       0.95  # Validate Newcombe (1998) prec_riskdiff(p1 = 56/70, p2 = 48/80, n1 = 70, r = 70/80, met = "newcombe")  # Table IIa #>  #>      precision for a risk difference with newcombe confidence interval  #>  #>    p1  p2 n1 n2 ntot     r delta        lwr       upr conf.width conf.level #> 1 0.8 0.6 70 80  150 0.875   0.2 0.05243147 0.3338727  0.2814412       0.95 prec_riskdiff(p1 = 10/10, p2 = 0/10, n1 = 10, met = "newcombe")  # Table IIh #>  #>      precision for a risk difference with newcombe confidence interval  #>  #>   p1 p2 n1 n2 ntot r delta       lwr upr conf.width conf.level #> 1  1  0 10 10   20 1     1 0.6075094   1  0.3924906       0.95  # multiple scenarios prec_riskdiff(p1 = c(56/70, 9/10, 6/7, 5/56),               p2 = c(48/80, 3/10, 2/7, 0/29),               n1 = c(70, 10, 7, 56),               r = c(70/80, 1, 1, 56/29),               method = "wald") #>  #>      precision for a risk difference with wald confidence interval  #>  #>           p1        p2 n1 n2 ntot        r      delta        lwr       upr #> 1 0.80000000 0.6000000 70 80  150 0.875000 0.20000000 0.05750490 0.3424951 #> 2 0.90000000 0.3000000 10 10   20 1.000000 0.60000000 0.26052428 0.9394757 #> 3 0.85714286 0.2857143  7  7   14 1.000000 0.57142857 0.14811614 0.9947410 #> 4 0.08928571 0.0000000 56 29   85 1.931034 0.08928571 0.01460024 0.1639712 #>   conf.width conf.level #> 1  0.2849902       0.95 #> 2  0.6789514       0.95 #> 3  0.8466249       0.95 #> 4  0.1493709       0.95

title: Sample size or precision for risk ratio — prec_riskratio
text: Exactly one parameters n1 conf.width must passed NULL, parameter determined . Koopman (koopman) provides asymptotic score confidence interval always consistent Pearsons chi-squared test. recommended interval (Fagerland et al.). Katz (katz) use logarithmic transformation calculate confidence interval. CI computed one proportions zero. proportions 1, estimate standard error becomes zero, resulting CI [1, 1]. uniroot used solve n katz, koopman method.

code: # confidence interval width with n   prec_sens(.6, 50) #> Warning: more than one method was chosen, 'wilson' will be used #>  #>      precision for a sensitivity with Wilson confidence interval.  #>  #>   sens   sensadj  n prev ntot conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1  0.6 0.5928652 50   NA   NA  0.2621017       0.95 0.4618144 0.7239161 #>  #> NOTE: sensadj is the adjusted sensitivity, from which the ci is calculated. #>       n is the number of positives, ntot the full sample #>    # confidence interval width with ntot and prevalence (assuming 50% prev)   prec_sens(.6, ntot = 100, prev = .5) #> estimating n from 'ntot' and 'prev' #> Warning: more than one method was chosen, 'wilson' will be used #>  #>      precision for a sensitivity with Wilson confidence interval.  #>  #>   sens   sensadj  n prev ntot conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1  0.6 0.5928652 50  0.5  100  0.2621017       0.95 0.4618144 0.7239161 #>  #> NOTE: sensadj is the adjusted sensitivity, from which the ci is calculated. #>       n is the number of positives, ntot the full sample #>    # sample size with confidence interval width   prec_sens(.6, conf.width = 0.262) #> Warning: more than one method was chosen, 'wilson' will be used #>  #>      sample size for a sensitivity with Wilson confidence interval.  #>  #>   sens   sensadj        n prev ntot conf.width conf.level       lwr       upr #> 1  0.6 0.5928708 50.04169   NA   NA      0.262       0.95 0.4618708 0.7238708 #>  #> NOTE: sensadj is the adjusted sensitivity, from which the ci is calculated. #>       n is the number of positives, ntot the full sample #>
